docs.title: PipeOps CLI Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the comprehensive documentation for PipeOps CLI - a powerful command-line interface designed to simplify managing cloud-native environments, deploying projects, and interacting with the PipeOps platform.

docs.title: 🚀 What is PipeOps CLI?
docs.text:
PipeOps CLI is a modern, cross-platform command-line tool that provides a unified interface for:

  • 🔐 Authentication: Secure OAuth-based authentication with PKCE flow
  • 📦 Project Management: Create, manage, and deploy projects seamlessly
  • 🚀 Server Management: Provision and configure servers across multiple environments
  • 🔧 Pipeline Management: Create, manage, and deploy CI/CD pipelines
  • 🤖 Agent Setup: Install and configure PipeOps agents for various platforms
  • 🌐 Cross-Platform Support: Available for Linux, Windows, macOS, and FreeBSD

docs.title: 🎯 Key Features
docs.text:
• Beautiful Terminal UI: Rich interface with colors, progress indicators, and intuitive design
  • Comprehensive Command Set: Over 20 commands covering all aspects of cloud-native management
  • Docker Support: Run in containers with full functionality
  • CI/CD Ready: Perfect for automation and integration workflows
  • Extensive Documentation: Detailed guides, examples, and API references

docs.title: 🏃‍♂️ Quick Start
docs.text:
Get started with PipeOps CLI in just a few steps:

  1. Install the CLI: 

    curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/main/install.sh | sh

  2. Authenticate: 

    pipeops auth login

  3. List your projects: 

    pipeops project list

  4. Get help: 

    pipeops --help

docs.title: Latest Features
docs.text:
• Enhanced Agent Installation: Full support for PipeOps agent installation with intelligent cluster detection
  • Multi-Platform Support: Native support for k3s, minikube, k3d, and kind clusters
  • Monitoring Integration: Built-in Prometheus, Loki, Grafana, and OpenCost stack
  • Worker Node Management: Easy joining of worker nodes to existing clusters

docs.text:

docs.title: Docker Usage
docs.text: Learn how to use PipeOps CLI in Docker containers for development, CI/CD, and production environments.

docs.title: Basic Usage
docs.text:
Run PipeOps CLI in a Docker container:

# Basic help
docker run --rm -it ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest --help

# Check version
docker run --rm -it ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest --version

docs.title: With Authentication
docs.text:
# Mount configuration file
docker run --rm -it \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Configure PipeOps CLI using environment variables:

# Run with environment variables
docker run --rm -it \
  -e PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-token" \
  -e PIPEOPS_API_URL="https://api.pipeops.io" \
  -e PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL="debug" \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

docs.title: Volume Mounts
docs.text:
Mount configuration and data directories:

# Mount config and data directories
docker run --rm -it \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  -v ~/.pipeops-data:/root/.pipeops-data \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest project list

docs.title: Basic Setup
docs.text:
version: '3.8'
services:
  pipeops-cli:
    image: ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest
    environment:
      - PIPEOPS_TOKEN=${PIPEOPS_TOKEN}
      - PIPEOPS_API_URL=https://api.pipeops.io
    volumes:
      - ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json
    command: ["project", "list"]

docs.title: Development Environment
docs.text:
version: '3.8'
services:
  pipeops-cli:
    image: ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest
    environment:
      - PIPEOPS_API_URL=https://dev-api.pipeops.io
      - PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL=debug
      - PIPEOPS_OUTPUT_FORMAT=json
    volumes:
      - ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json
      - ./scripts:/scripts
    working_dir: /scripts
    command: ["sh", "-c", "pipeops project list && pipeops server list"]

docs.title: CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text:
version: '3.8'
services:
  pipeops-deploy:
    image: ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest
    environment:
      - PIPEOPS_TOKEN=${PIPEOPS_SERVICE_TOKEN}
      - PIPEOPS_API_URL=https://api.pipeops.io
      - PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL=info
      - PIPEOPS_OUTPUT_FORMAT=json
    volumes:
      - ./deploy:/deploy
    working_dir: /deploy
    command: ["sh", "-c", "pipeops deploy create --name production --image my-app:$BUILD_NUMBER"]

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
# Interactive development session
docker run --rm -it \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  -v $(pwd):/workspace \
  --workdir /workspace \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest

# Run specific commands
docker run --rm -it \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest project create my-project

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# Deploy from CI/CD
docker run --rm \
  -e PIPEOPS_TOKEN="${PIPEOPS_SERVICE_TOKEN}" \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest deploy create \
  --name production \
  --image my-app:${BUILD_NUMBER}

docs.title: Automation Scripts
docs.text:
# Automated deployment script
docker run --rm \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  -v $(pwd)/scripts:/scripts \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest \
  sh -c "cd /scripts && ./deploy.sh"

docs.title: Token Management
docs.text:
# Use environment variables for tokens
docker run --rm -it \
  -e PIPEOPS_TOKEN="$(cat ~/.pipeops-token)" \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

# Use Docker secrets (Docker Swarm)
docker service create \
  --secret source=pipeops-token,target=/run/secrets/pipeops-token \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest \
  sh -c "export PIPEOPS_TOKEN=\$(cat /run/secrets/pipeops-token) && pipeops auth status"

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:
# Use custom network
docker network create pipeops-network

docker run --rm -it \
  --network pipeops-network \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

docs.title: Resource Limits
docs.text:
# Set resource limits
docker run --rm -it \
  --memory="512m" \
  --cpus="0.5" \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest project list

docs.title: Version Pinning

docs.title: Log Collection

docs.title: Health Checks

docs.title: Volume Mount Issues

docs.title: Agent Commands
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to PipeOps agent installation and management commands.

docs.title: 🤖 Overview
docs.text: PipeOps agents enable you to manage Kubernetes clusters seamlessly. The agent commands provide functionality to install, configure, and manage PipeOps agents across different Kubernetes distributions.

docs.title: 📋 Available Commands
docs.text: Command Description Usage install Install PipeOps agent and Kubernetes cluster pipeops agent install [token] join Join worker node to existing cluster pipeops agent join <server-url> <token> info Show cluster information and join commands pipeops agent info

docs.title: Basic Installation
docs.text:
Install PipeOps agent with automatic cluster detection:

# Install with token as argument
pipeops agent install your-token-here

# Install using environment variables
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-token"
export CLUSTER_NAME="my-cluster"
pipeops agent install

docs.title: Cluster Type Selection
docs.text:
Choose your Kubernetes distribution:

# Specify cluster type
pipeops agent install --cluster-type k3s
pipeops agent install --cluster-type minikube
pipeops agent install --cluster-type k3d
pipeops agent install --cluster-type kind
pipeops agent install --cluster-type auto  # Default

docs.title: Cluster Naming
docs.text:
Set a custom name for your cluster:

# Set cluster name
pipeops agent install --cluster-name "production-cluster"

docs.title: Monitoring Stack
docs.text:
Control monitoring stack installation:

# Install without monitoring stack
pipeops agent install --no-monitoring

# Install with monitoring (default)
pipeops agent install

docs.title: Existing Cluster Installation
docs.text:
Install agent on an existing Kubernetes cluster:

# Install on existing cluster
pipeops agent install --existing-cluster --cluster-name="my-existing-cluster"

docs.title: Installation Flags
docs.text: Flag Description Default --cluster-name Name for the cluster pipeops-cluster --cluster-type Kubernetes distribution (k3s|minikube|k3d|kind|auto) auto --existing-cluster Install agent on existing Kubernetes cluster false --no-monitoring Skip installation of monitoring stack false --update Update the agent to the latest version false --uninstall Uninstall the agent and monitoring stack false

docs.title: Basic Join
docs.text:
Join a worker node to an existing cluster:

# Join with server URL and token
pipeops agent join https://192.168.1.100:6443 abc123def456

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Use environment variables for joining:

# Set environment variables
export K3S_URL="https://192.168.1.100:6443"
export K3S_TOKEN="abc123def456"

# Join using environment variables
pipeops agent join

docs.title: View Cluster Info
docs.text:
Get cluster information and join commands:

# Show cluster information
pipeops agent info

This command displays: - Server URL for joining worker nodes - Join token for worker nodes - Cluster status and configuration - Connection details

docs.title: 🌍 Environment Variables
docs.text:
The agent commands support various environment variables:

Variable Description Required PIPEOPS_TOKEN Control plane token Yes CLUSTER_NAME Cluster name No CLUSTER_TYPE Kubernetes distribution No K3S_URL Server URL for joining Yes (for join) K3S_TOKEN Token for joining Yes (for join) INSTALL_MONITORING Enable/disable monitoring No

docs.title: Complete Installation Workflow
docs.text:
# 1. Install agent with monitoring
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-token"
export CLUSTER_NAME="production-cluster"
pipeops agent install

# 2. Get cluster information
pipeops agent info

# 3. Join additional worker nodes
export K3S_URL="https://192.168.1.100:6443"
export K3S_TOKEN="abc123def456"
pipeops agent join

docs.title: Development Environment Setup
docs.text:
# Install lightweight cluster for development
pipeops agent install \
  --cluster-name "dev-cluster" \
  --cluster-type k3s \
  --no-monitoring

docs.title: Production Environment Setup
docs.text:
# Install production cluster with monitoring
pipeops agent install \
  --cluster-name "production-cluster" \
  --cluster-type auto \
  --cluster-name "prod-k8s"

docs.title: Existing Cluster Integration
docs.text:
# Install agent on existing cluster
pipeops agent install \
  --existing-cluster \
  --cluster-name "existing-cluster" \
  --no-monitoring

docs.title: Update Agent
docs.text:
Update the agent to the latest version:

# Update agent
pipeops agent install --update

docs.title: Uninstall Agent
docs.text:
Remove the agent and monitoring stack:

# Uninstall agent
pipeops agent install --uninstall

docs.title: ✅ Verification
docs.text:
After installation, verify the setup:

# Check agent pods
kubectl get pods -n pipeops-system

# Check monitoring pods
kubectl get pods -n pipeops-monitoring

# Check cluster nodes
kubectl get nodes

# Check agent logs
kubectl logs deployment/pipeops-agent -n pipeops-system

docs.title: Installation Fails
docs.text:
# Check token validity
pipeops auth status

# Verify network connectivity
curl -I https://api.pipeops.io

# Check system requirements
pipeops agent install --help

docs.title: Join Fails
docs.text:
# Verify server URL
curl -k https://192.168.1.100:6443/version

# Check token validity
echo $K3S_TOKEN

# Verify network connectivity
ping 192.168.1.100

docs.title: Agent Not Starting
docs.text:
# Check agent logs
kubectl logs deployment/pipeops-agent -n pipeops-system

# Check agent status
kubectl get pods -n pipeops-system

# Restart agent
kubectl rollout restart deployment/pipeops-agent -n pipeops-system

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
Enable debug logging:

# Set debug log level
export PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL=debug

# Run installation with debug
pipeops agent install --verbose

  • Never commit tokens to version control

docs.title: Network Security
docs.text:

  • Configure firewall rules appropriately
  • Consider VPN for remote access
  • Monitor network traffic

docs.title: Commands Overview
docs.text: This page provides a comprehensive overview of all PipeOps CLI commands, their usage, and examples.

docs.title: 📋 Command Structure
docs.text:
PipeOps CLI follows a hierarchical command structure:

pipeops <command> <subcommand> [flags] [arguments]

docs.title: 🔐 Authentication Commands
docs.text: Manage authentication and user details.

docs.title: pipeops auth login
docs.text:
Authenticate with PipeOps using OAuth.

# Interactive login
pipeops auth login

# Login with specific provider
pipeops auth login --provider github

docs.title: pipeops auth logout
docs.text:
Log out from PipeOps.

pipeops auth logout

docs.title: pipeops auth status
docs.text:
Check authentication status and user information.

pipeops auth status

docs.title: pipeops auth me
docs.text:
Display current user information.

pipeops auth me

docs.title: 📦 Project Commands
docs.text: Manage PipeOps projects.

docs.title: pipeops project list
docs.text:
List all projects.

# List all projects
pipeops project list

# List with JSON output
pipeops project list --json

docs.title: pipeops project create
docs.text:
Create a new project.

# Create project with name
pipeops project create my-project

# Create with description
pipeops project create my-project --description "My awesome project"

docs.title: pipeops project logs
docs.text:
View project logs.

# View recent logs
pipeops project logs my-project

# Follow logs in real-time
pipeops project logs my-project --follow

# View logs with timestamps
pipeops project logs my-project --timestamps

docs.title: 🚀 Deployment Commands
docs.text: Manage deployments and pipelines.

docs.title: pipeops deploy pipeline
docs.text:
Manage deployment pipelines.

# Create new pipeline
pipeops deploy pipeline create --name my-pipeline

# List pipelines
pipeops deploy pipeline list

# Get pipeline status
pipeops deploy pipeline status my-pipeline

docs.title: pipeops deploy create
docs.text:
Create a new deployment.

# Deploy with image
pipeops deploy create --name my-app --image nginx:latest

# Deploy with environment variables
pipeops deploy create --name my-app --image my-app:latest --env KEY=value

docs.title: pipeops deploy status
docs.text:
Check deployment status.

# Check specific deployment
pipeops deploy status my-app

# Check all deployments
pipeops deploy status --all

docs.title: pipeops deploy logs
docs.text:
View deployment logs.

# View logs
pipeops deploy logs my-app

# Follow logs
pipeops deploy logs my-app --follow

docs.title: 🖥️ Server Commands
docs.text: Manage servers and infrastructure.

docs.title: pipeops server list
docs.text:
List all servers.

# List servers
pipeops server list

# List with details
pipeops server list --verbose

docs.title: pipeops server deploy
docs.text:
Deploy to a server.

# Deploy application
pipeops server deploy --name my-app --server server-1

docs.title: ⚙️ Agent Commands
docs.text: Manage PipeOps agents for Kubernetes clusters.

docs.title: pipeops agent install
docs.text:
Install PipeOps agent and Kubernetes cluster.

# Install with token
pipeops agent install your-token-here

# Install using environment variables
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-token"
export CLUSTER_NAME="my-cluster"
pipeops agent install

# Install on existing cluster
pipeops agent install --existing-cluster --cluster-name="my-existing-cluster"

# Install without monitoring
pipeops agent install --no-monitoring

# Update agent
pipeops agent install --update

# Uninstall agent
pipeops agent install --uninstall

docs.title: pipeops agent join
docs.text:
Join worker node to existing cluster.

# Join with server URL and token
pipeops agent join https://192.168.1.100:6443 abc123def456

# Join using environment variables
export K3S_URL="https://192.168.1.100:6443"
export K3S_TOKEN="abc123def456"
pipeops agent join

docs.title: pipeops agent info
docs.text:
Show cluster information and join commands.

pipeops agent info

docs.title: ☸️ K3s Commands
docs.text: Manage K3s clusters.

docs.title: pipeops k3s install
docs.text:
Install K3s server.

# Install K3s
pipeops k3s install

# Install with specific version
pipeops k3s install --version v1.28.0

docs.title: pipeops k3s join
docs.text:
Join worker node to K3s cluster.

# Join worker node
pipeops k3s join --server https://192.168.1.100:6443 --token abc123

docs.title: pipeops k3s restart
docs.text:
Restart K3s service.

# Restart K3s
pipeops k3s restart

docs.title: pipeops k3s kill
docs.text:
Stop K3s service.

# Stop K3s
pipeops k3s kill

docs.title: pipeops status
docs.text:
Show overall system status.

# Check system status
pipeops status

# Check with verbose output
pipeops status --verbose

docs.title: pipeops version
docs.text:
Show version information.

# Show version
pipeops version

# Show version with build info
pipeops version --verbose

docs.title: pipeops update
docs.text:
Update PipeOps CLI.

# Check for updates
pipeops update check

# Update to latest version
pipeops update

docs.title: pipeops proxy
docs.text:
Manage proxy connections.

# Start proxy
pipeops proxy start --port 8080

# Stop proxy
pipeops proxy stop

docs.title: 🌐 Global Flags
docs.text:
All commands support these global flags:

Flag Description Example --help, -h Show help for command pipeops auth --help --version, -v Show version information pipeops --version --json Output in JSON format pipeops project list --json --verbose Enable verbose output pipeops status --verbose --quiet, -q Suppress non-essential output pipeops deploy create --quiet --config Use custom config file pipeops --config ~/.pipeops-custom.json

docs.title: Daily Workflow
docs.text:

pipeops project list

# Deploy

# Verify

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text: We welcome contributions to PipeOps CLI! This guide will help you get started with contributing to the project.

docs.title: 1. Fork and Clone
docs.text:
# Fork the repository on GitHub, then clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/pipeops-cli.git
cd pipeops-cli

# Add upstream remote
git remote add upstream https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli.git

docs.title: 2. Set Up Development Environment
docs.text:
# Install Go (1.23 or later)
# Follow instructions at https://golang.org/doc/install

# Install dependencies
go mod download

# Build the project
make build

# Run tests
make test

# Run linter
make lint

docs.title: 3. Create a Branch
docs.text:
# Create a new branch for your feature
git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

# Or for bug fixes
git checkout -b fix/your-bug-fix

docs.title: 4. Make Changes
docs.text:
• Write clear, commented code
  • Follow Go best practices and conventions
  • Add tests for new functionality
  • Update documentation as needed

docs.title: 5. Test Your Changes
docs.text:
# Run all tests
make test

# Run specific tests
go test ./cmd/agent/...

# Run linter
make lint

# Build and test the binary
make build
./pipeops-cli --help

docs.title: 6. Commit and Push
docs.text:
# Add your changes
git add .

# Commit with a descriptive message
git commit -m "feat: add new agent installation feature"

# Push to your fork
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: 7. Create a Pull Request
docs.text:
• Go to your fork on GitHub
  • Click "New Pull Request"
  • Fill out the pull request template
  • Submit the pull request

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• Follow Go conventions and best practices
  • Use gofmt to format code
  • Use golint for linting
  • Write clear, self-documenting code

docs.title: Commit Messages
docs.text:
Follow the Conventional Commits specification:

feat: add new feature
fix: fix a bug
docs: update documentation
style: formatting changes
refactor: code refactoring
test: add or update tests
chore: maintenance tasks

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Write unit tests for new functionality
  • Test edge cases and error conditions
  • Ensure tests pass before submitting PR
  • Aim for good test coverage

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Update documentation for new features
  • Add examples and usage instructions
  • Update command help text
  • Follow the existing documentation style

docs.title: 🏗️ Project Structure
docs.text:
pipeops-cli/
├── cmd/                 # CLI commands

docs.title: Example Test
docs.text:
func TestInstallCommand(t *testing.T) {
    tests := []struct {
        name     string
        args     []string
        expected string
    }{
        {
            name:     "valid token",
            args:     []string{"valid-token"},
            expected: "success",
        },
        {
            name:     "empty token",
            args:     []string{""},
            expected: "error",
        },
    }

    for _, tt := range tests {
        t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T) {
            // Test implementation
        })
    }
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Learn how to configure PipeOps CLI for your specific needs and environment.

docs.title: 📁 Configuration File
docs.text: PipeOps CLI stores configuration in ~/.pipeops.json by default. You can specify a custom location using the --config flag or PIPEOPS_CONFIG_PATH environment variable.

docs.title: Configuration Structure
docs.text:
{
  "version": {
    "version": "1.0.0"
  },
  "updates": {
    "last_update_check": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z",
    "skip_update_check": false
  },
  "service_account_token": "your-token-here",
  "api_url": "https://api.pipeops.io",
  "log_level": "info",
  "output_format": "text"
}

docs.title: 🌍 Environment Variables
docs.text: Configure PipeOps CLI using environment variables:

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
# Service account token
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-service-account-token"

# API endpoint
export PIPEOPS_API_URL="https://api.pipeops.io"

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
# Custom config file location
export PIPEOPS_CONFIG_PATH="$HOME/.pipeops-custom.json"

# Log level
export PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL="debug"  # debug, info, warn, error

# Output format
export PIPEOPS_OUTPUT_FORMAT="json"  # text, json

docs.title: Agent Configuration
docs.text:
# Cluster settings
export CLUSTER_NAME="my-cluster"
export CLUSTER_TYPE="k3s"  # k3s, minikube, k3d, kind, auto

# Monitoring
export INSTALL_MONITORING="true"  # true, false

# K3s settings
export K3S_URL="https://192.168.1.100:6443"
export K3S_TOKEN="your-k3s-token"

docs.title: API Configuration
docs.text:
# Set custom API endpoint
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set api_url "https://custom-api.pipeops.io"

# Set timeout
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set timeout "30s"

docs.title: Logging Configuration
docs.text:
# Set log level
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set log_level "debug"

# Set log format
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set log_format "json"

docs.title: Update Configuration
docs.text:
# Disable automatic update checks
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set skip_update_check true

# Set update check interval
pipeops --config ~/.pipeops.json config set update_check_interval "24h"

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
# Run with custom configuration
docker run --rm -it \
  -e PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-token" \
  -e PIPEOPS_API_URL="https://api.pipeops.io" \
  -e PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL="debug" \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

docs.title: Docker Compose
docs.text:
version: '3.8'
services:
  pipeops-cli:
    image: ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest
    environment:
      - PIPEOPS_TOKEN=${PIPEOPS_TOKEN}
      - PIPEOPS_API_URL=https://api.pipeops.io
      - PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL=info
    volumes:
      - ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json
    command: ["project", "list"]

docs.title: Token Management
docs.text:
# Store token securely
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="$(cat ~/.pipeops-token)"

# Use keychain (macOS)
security add-generic-password -a "pipeops" -s "pipeops-token" -w "your-token"

# Retrieve from keychain
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="$(security find-generic-password -a "pipeops" -s "pipeops-token" -w)"

docs.title: TLS Configuration
docs.text:
# Skip TLS verification (not recommended for production)
export PIPEOPS_TLS_INSECURE_SKIP_VERIFY="true"

# Custom CA certificate
export PIPEOPS_TLS_CA_CERT="/path/to/ca.crt"

pipeops --json project list

pipeops project list --json

docs.title: Custom Output Format

pipeops project list --format text

pipeops config set auto_update true

# Set update channel
pipeops config set update_channel "stable"  # stable, beta, alpha

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers various methods to install PipeOps CLI on different platforms.

docs.title: macOS & Linux (Recommended)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install PipeOps CLI is using our installation script:

curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/main/install.sh | sh

This script will: - Detect your operating system and architecture - Download the appropriate binary - Install it to /usr/local/bin/pipeops - Verify the installation

docs.title: Windows (PowerShell)
docs.text:
For Windows users, use our PowerShell installation script:

irm https://raw.githubusercontent.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/main/install.ps1 | iex

docs.title: Homebrew (macOS/Linux)
docs.text:
Install using Homebrew:

# Add the PipeOps tap
brew tap pipeops/pipeops

# Install PipeOps CLI
brew install pipeops

docs.title: Go Install
docs.text:
If you have Go installed, you can install directly from source:

go install github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli@latest

docs.title: Docker
docs.text:
Run PipeOps CLI in a Docker container:

# Basic usage
docker run --rm -it ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest --help

# With persistent configuration
docker run --rm -it \
  -v ~/.pipeops.json:/root/.pipeops.json \
  ghcr.io/pipeopshq/pipeops-cli:latest auth status

docs.title: Download Binaries
docs.text: Download the appropriate binary for your platform from the releases page:

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# x86_64
wget https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/releases/latest/download/pipeops-cli_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz
tar -xzf pipeops-cli_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz
sudo mv pipeops /usr/local/bin/

# ARM64
wget https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/releases/latest/download/pipeops-cli_Linux_arm64.tar.gz
tar -xzf pipeops-cli_Linux_arm64.tar.gz
sudo mv pipeops /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
# Intel Mac
wget https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/releases/latest/download/pipeops-cli_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz
tar -xzf pipeops-cli_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz
sudo mv pipeops /usr/local/bin/

# Apple Silicon (M1/M2)
wget https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/releases/latest/download/pipeops-cli_Darwin_arm64.tar.gz
tar -xzf pipeops-cli_Darwin_arm64.tar.gz
sudo mv pipeops /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
# Download the Windows binary
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/releases/latest/download/pipeops-cli_Windows_x86_64.zip" -OutFile "pipeops-cli.zip"

# Extract and add to PATH
Expand-Archive -Path "pipeops-cli.zip" -DestinationPath "C:\pipeops"
$env:PATH += ";C:\pipeops"

docs.title: ✅ Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify that PipeOps CLI is working correctly:

# Check version
pipeops --version

# Check help
pipeops --help

# Check authentication status
pipeops auth status

docs.title: Homebrew
docs.text:
brew update
brew upgrade pipeops

docs.title: Go Install
docs.text: go install github.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli@latest

docs.title: Using CLI Update Command
docs.text:
PipeOps CLI can update itself:

# Check for updates
pipeops update check

# Update to latest version
pipeops update

docs.title: Manual Update
docs.text:
Download the latest release and replace the existing binary:

# Download latest version
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/main/install.sh | sh

docs.title: macOS & Linux
docs.text:
# Remove binary
sudo rm /usr/local/bin/pipeops

# Remove configuration (optional)
rm ~/.pipeops.json

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
# Remove from PATH and delete files
Remove-Item "C:\pipeops\pipeops.exe" -Force
# Remove from PATH environment variable manually

docs.title: Homebrew
docs.text:
brew uninstall pipeops
brew untap pipeops/pipeops

docs.title: Permission Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter permission issues during installation:

# Make sure the install directory is writable
sudo chown -R $(whoami) /usr/local/bin

# Or install to user directory
mkdir -p ~/.local/bin
mv pipeops ~/.local/bin
echo 'export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Binary Not Found
docs.text:
If the pipeops command is not found:

  1. Check if it's in your PATH: 

    which pipeops
echo $PATH

  2. Add to PATH (if needed): 

    echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Network Issues
docs.text:
If you're behind a corporate firewall or proxy:

# Set proxy environment variables
export HTTP_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080
export HTTPS_PROXY=http://proxy.company.com:8080

# Then run installation
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/PipeOpsHQ/pipeops-cli/main/install.sh | sh

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Get up and running with PipeOps CLI in just a few minutes. This guide will walk you through the essential steps to start using PipeOps CLI effectively.

docs.title: 🚀 Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have:

  • PipeOps CLI installed (see Installation)
  • A PipeOps account (sign up at pipeops.io)
  • Basic familiarity with command-line interfaces

docs.title: 📋 Step 1: Verify Installation
docs.text:
First, let's make sure PipeOps CLI is properly installed:

# Check version
pipeops --version

# View available commands
pipeops --help

You should see output similar to:

🚀 PipeOps CLI Version: 1.0.0

Usage:
  pipeops [command]

Available Commands:
  agent       ⚙️ Manage agent-related commands and tasks
  auth        🔐 Authentication and user management
  deploy      🚀 Deploy applications and pipelines
  project     📦 Project management
  server      🖥️ Server management
  k3s         ☸️ K3s cluster management
  help        Help about any command

docs.title: 🔐 Step 2: Authenticate
docs.text:
Authenticate with your PipeOps account:

pipeops auth login

This will:

  1. Open your default web browser
  2. Redirect you to the PipeOps authentication page
  3. Complete the OAuth flow
  4. Save your credentials locally

Authentication Methods

PipeOps CLI supports multiple authentication methods: - OAuth (Recommended): Secure browser-based authentication - Service Account Token: For CI/CD and automation - Environment Variables: For containerized environments

docs.title: Verify Authentication
docs.text:
Check your authentication status:

pipeops auth status

You should see your user information and authentication status.

docs.title: 📦 Step 3: Explore Your Projects
docs.text:
List your existing projects:

pipeops project list

If you don't have any projects yet, you can create one:

pipeops project create my-first-project

docs.title: 🚀 Step 4: Deploy Your First Application
docs.text:
Let's deploy a simple application to see PipeOps CLI in action:

# Create a new deployment
pipeops deploy create --name hello-world --image nginx:latest

# Check deployment status
pipeops deploy status hello-world

# View deployment logs
pipeops deploy logs hello-world

docs.title: 🤖 Step 5: Set Up an Agent (Optional)
docs.text:
If you want to manage Kubernetes clusters, install a PipeOps agent:

# Install agent with automatic cluster detection
pipeops agent install your-token-here

# Or install on existing cluster
pipeops agent install --existing-cluster --cluster-name="my-cluster"

docs.title: 📊 Step 6: Monitor and Manage
docs.text:
Use these commands to monitor and manage your resources:

# Check server status
pipeops server list

# View project logs
pipeops project logs my-first-project

# Get system status
pipeops status

docs.title: Daily Operations
docs.text:
# Morning routine - check status
pipeops auth status
pipeops project list
pipeops server list

# Deploy updates
pipeops deploy update my-app --image my-app:v2.0

# Monitor deployments
pipeops deploy logs my-app --follow

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
# Create new project
pipeops project create my-dev-project

# Deploy development environment
pipeops deploy create --name dev-env --image my-app:dev

# Test locally
pipeops proxy start --port 8080

# Clean up
pipeops deploy delete dev-env

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
# Authenticate with service account
export PIPEOPS_TOKEN="your-service-account-token"

# Deploy from CI/CD
pipeops deploy create --name production --image my-app:$BUILD_NUMBER

# Verify deployment
pipeops deploy status production

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set up environment variables for automation:

# Add to your shell profile (~/.bashrc, ~/.zshrc, etc.)
export PIPEOPS_API_URL="https://api.pipeops.io"
export PIPEOPS_LOG_LEVEL="info"
export PIPEOPS_CONFIG_PATH="$HOME/.pipeops.json"

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
PipeOps CLI stores configuration in ~/.pipeops.json:

{
  "version": {
    "version": "1.0.0"
  },
  "updates": {
    "last_update_check": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z",
    "skip_update_check": false
  },
  "service_account_token": "your-token-here"
}

docs.title: 📚 Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you're up and running, explore these areas:

  • Commands Overview: Complete command reference
  • Project Management: Advanced project operations
  • Deployment Guide: Complex deployment scenarios
  • Agent Management: Kubernetes cluster management
  • Docker Usage: Containerized workflows
  • CI/CD Integration: Automation and pipelines

docs.text:
If you run into issues:

  1. Check command help: pipeops <command> --help
  2. View logs: pipeops logs <resource>
  3. Check status: pipeops status
  4. Review troubleshooting guide
  5. Join our Discord community

docs.title: 🎉 Congratulations!
docs.text:
You've successfully set up PipeOps CLI and completed your first operations. You're now ready to:

  • ✅ Manage projects and deployments
  • ✅ Monitor your infrastructure
  • ✅ Set up automated workflows
  • ✅ Scale your applications

Happy deploying! 🚀

docs.title: Version Numbering
docs.text:
We use Semantic Versioning for version numbering:

  • MAJOR version when you make incompatible API changes
  • MINOR version when you add functionality in a backwards compatible manner
  • PATCH version when you make backwards compatible bug fixes

docs.title: Release Schedule
docs.text:
• Major releases: Every 6 months
  • Minor releases: Every month
  • Patch releases: As needed for bug fixes
  • Security releases: As needed for security fixes

docs.title: Support Policy
docs.text:
• Current version: Full support
  • Previous major version: Security fixes only
  • Older versions: No support

docs.title: Migration Guide
docs.text:
For major version changes, we provide migration guides:

  • v1.0.0 Migration Guide
  • v0.9.0 Migration Guide

docs.title: Breaking Changes
docs.text: Breaking changes are documented in the Breaking Changes file.

docs.title: Deprecation Policy
docs.text:
• Features are deprecated for at least one minor version before removal
  • Deprecation warnings are shown in the CLI
  • Deprecated features are documented in the changelog

docs.title: Security Updates
docs.text:
Security updates are released as needed and are documented in the Security Advisories file.

This changelog is maintained by the PipeOps team and is updated with each release.
